title-group.article-title: An investigation into potential fuel savings for 110–130 seat passenger transport aircraft due to the incorporation of natural laminar flow or hybrid laminar flow control on the engine nacelles

contrib-group.aff: Department of Mechanical, Biomedical and Aeronautical Engineering, Materials and Surface Science Institute, University of Limerick, Ireland

author-notes.corresp: Trevor M Young, Department of Mechanical, Biomedical and Aeronautical Engineering, Materials and Surface Science Institute, University of Limerick, Limerick, Ireland. Email: trevor.young@ul.ie

abstract.p: A computer program, capable of accurately determining the required fuel for a given mission profile, has been developed for two ‘project’ aircraft types. The program was initially validated against reference aircraft and then modified to study the potential impact on trip fuel due to the incorporation of natural laminar flow or hybrid laminar flow control on the engine nacelles, by implementing changes the aircraft’s drag coefficient (CD), specific fuel consumption and operating empty weight. Trade studies, with changes to CD, specific fuel consumption and operating empty weight, were conducted using trip fuel as the objective function. The results can be superimposed, permitting estimates of the trip fuel reduction due to the incorporation of alternative drag reduction designs. The impact of trip distance on the fuel-saving potential of laminar flow technologies has also been explored. The potential fuel savings for the aircraft fleet (with the incorporation of hybrid laminar flow control or natural laminar flow) has been estimated using an aircraft utilisation model (representing the probability of the aircraft flying a given stage length). It was concluded that there would be a net fuel saving based on the utilisation model. Finally, to obtain a realistic assessment of the potential benefit of these technologies, the probable time-in-cloud, which will result in a loss of laminar flow, has been considered.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Hybrid laminar flow control (HLFC) is an active drag reduction technique that facilitates extended runs of laminar flow (LF) on aircraft surfaces at chord Reynolds numbers normally associated with turbulent flow. The most widely adopted approach involves sucking small amounts of air through a perforated surface to suppress boundary layer instabilities. A HLFC surface has a forward active control (i.e. suction) region and an aft region that maintains the boundary layer in a laminar state by means of a favourable pressure gradient (i.e. natural laminar flow or NLF). HLFC has being considered for the wing, empennage and engine nacelles of jet transport aeroplanes to reduce drag and fuel consumption.1–4 Unlike the wing and empennage on these aircraft, an engine nacelle essentially has no sweep on the nose section. The laminar-to-turbulent flow transition mechanisms (i.e. Tollmien–Schlichting, cross-flow and attachment line contamination) that exist due to sweep are thus not present on a nacelle. NLF can therefore be employed on a nacelle, albeit with a smaller LF region than would be possible with HLFC.

The application of LF technologies to engine nacelles has been the subject of several investigations. Major research and development projects include those conducted by General Electric Aircraft Engines (ca. 1991–1992),5 Rolls-Royce/DLR (ca. 1990–1993)6 and, more recently, by Boeing with its application on the B787,7 by Aircelle on the NAIAD demonstrator8 and by Bombardier Aerospace within a Rolls-Royce-led consortium in the Environmentally Friendly Engine (EFE) project.9,10 LF nacelles have also been studied in several collaborative research projects funded by the European Commission – these include projects LARA,11,12 ELFIN II,12 HYLDA13 and ALTTA.14

The chordwise extent of LF that can be achieved on a nacelle depends on the design approach. LF of 5% of the nacelle chord, for example, can be achieved through NLF with a modest change to the nacelle profile, but it would only yield a very small drag benefit. HLFC can extend LF to almost 50% of the nacelle chord13 and can reduce the nacelle friction drag by 35–40%.5,13 This translates to a reduction in the total drag of the aircraft of approximately 1–2%.6,14,15

Converting predicted drag reduction values into a forecast of the amount of fuel that can be saved by an aircraft when considering actual operational conditions is, however, a non-trivial exercise. The situation is further complicated when an entire fleet, with different mission profiles, is considered in order to establish the potential net benefit of the technology. In this respect, there is little published information. The study herein reported has addressed this topic by explored the potential fuel saving that could be achieved under realistic operational scenarios for 130- and 110-seat twin-engine ‘project’ aircraft, in the class of the Bombardier CSeries, by the incorporation of either HLFC or NLF on the engine nacelles. The 130-seat aircraft is denoted as Model B (and an extended-range variant, Model BER) and the 110-seat variant is denoted as Model A (and an extended-range variant, Model AER). The study takes as its input prior-established drag reduction data, based on the chordwise positions of the laminar-to-turbulent transition of the boundary layer (corresponding to 5%, 20% or 40% of the nacelle chord).

There are several factors that need to be taken into account when evaluating the potential fuel-saving benefit of an aircraft with HLFC or NLF compared to a turbulent baseline (or reference) aircraft.
The benefits of drag reduction are eroded by an increase in the aircraft’s weight due to the installation of the HLFC system. To achieve NLF, a greater nacelle diameter is typically required (compared to a turbulent design), which in some cases can result in an increased nacelle weight.
The HLFC suction system requires power, which effectively means an increase in the power offtake from the engines. This increase may be considered as an increase in the aircraft’s specific fuel consumption (SFC).
LF cannot be guaranteed 100% of the time, due to the premature transition of the boundary layer that occurs when flying through clouds and from other localised factors, such as surface contamination from insects.
The HLFC system is likely to only be used above a threshold height (herein selected as 29,000 ft). This means that the block fuel elements of engine start, taxi, takeoff, initial climb and descent, are not reduced.

The main consequence of the last factor is that these drag reduction technologies favour longer trip distances over shorter distances. In fact, the trip distance is one of the most important parameters in assessing whether the drag reduction – and the resulting fuel saving – sufficiently offsets the weight increase and SFC penalty (and system complexity), in the case of HLFC. A fleet utilisation model, which provides a probability distribution of trip distances being flown by all operators, is thus critical information to properly assess the net potential benefit of these technologies.

The following objectives were established for this study.
To modify an existing computer program by developing representative engine and aerodynamic databases so as to enable the program to accurately calculate the trip fuel for the Model B and Model A aircraft (including extended-range variants).
To quantify the impact of HLFC and NLF on the required trip fuel for selected input parameters and to conduct trade (sensitivity) studies in which (a) drag reduction, (b) weight increase and (c) SFC increase are considered for different combinations of payload and range.
To quantify the influence of trip distance on the fuel savings that can be achieved with HLFC and NLF technologies.
To estimate the potential fuel saving of HLFC and NLF, under realistic operational conditions, for the entire fleet of Model B and Model A aircraft (included extended-range variants), compared to the equivalent turbulent aircraft, based on an aircraft utilisation model.

sec.title: Adopted approach
sec.p: The adopted approach involved initially modelling the en route performance of a current reference aircraft, the A319. The model was validated against available data. The engine and aerodynamic data were then adapted to best represent the performance of the Model B and Model A aircraft types. Finally, the computer models were adapted to take into account either (a) the installation of a HLFC system or (b) the redesign of the nacelle for NLF.

In the case of HLFC, the change involved a decrease in drag and an increase in SFC (during the part of the mission where the HLFC system would be operational) and an increase in the operating empty weight (OEW), resulting from the installation of the suction and monitoring systems. It was assumed that all other aircraft parameters remained unchanged, including the basic aerodynamic and powerplant characteristics.

sec.title: Fuel planning requirements (mission rules)
sec.p: The fuel planning requirements of Federal Aviation Regulation 121.639 (i.e. US domestic reserves) have been used. This means that the aircraft must have sufficient fuel to: (a) fly to the airport to which it is dispatched; thereafter, (b) fly to and land at the most distant alternate airport (where required) from the airport to which dispatched; and, thereafter, (c) fly for 45 min at normal cruising fuel consumption.16 In addition to the basic fuel requirements, operators are required to have an additional amount of fuel (i.e. contingency fuel) sufficient to provide for the increased consumption arising from potential contingencies (e.g. deviations of an individual aircraft from the expected fuel consumption or deviations from forecast meteorological conditions or from planned routings or cruising altitudes).

For theoretical study (or commercial advertising), an arbitrary assumption of the alternate distance is usually made: typically 100 nm for short trips and 200 nm for mid- or long-haul trips. A 100 nm alternate distance and a 5% en route contingency have been used in this study. The mission requirements (mission rules) for this study are reflected on the mission profile given in Figure 1. The segments of the mission during which the HLFC system would be operational are also indicted. Figure 1.

sec.title: Computer program
sec.p:
Classical mechanics of flight theory was used to develop the spreadsheet-based computer program used in this study. The main elements of the theory are presented elsewhere by Young.17–19 The original computer program was developed for the B757-200.20,21 At that time, it was checked against reliable/validated sources.22–29 Essentially, the program calculates the fuel consumed, distance covered and time elapsed for the aircraft performing the mission according to a defined flight profile, such as the one shown in Figure 1. The program has three user-selected modes.
Weight mode: this computes the range for user-specified brake release weight (BRW) and payload for a defined mission profile.
Range mode: this computes the BRW to satisfy user-specified range and payload for a defined mission profile.
Fuel mode: this computes the fuel required to fly a mission where the range, BRW and payload are all specified, and determines the fuel quantity on board at shut-down.

The program comprises a number of computational modules, which compute the fuel, distance and time for the climb, cruise and descent legs of the mission. These are integrated through a master computing table. Fuel, distance and time allowances are made for the remaining legs (e.g. start-up, taxi, takeoff and climb to 1500 ft and landing) so that trip fuel, distance and time can be determined from engine start to shut-down at the destination airport. The computation occurs sequentially, using the specified BRW (for Modes 1 and 3) or an assumed BRW (for Mode 2) as the starting point. For each leg of the mission, the fuel used is determined and the aircraft’s weight updated.

The climb is broken into vertical intervals of 5000 ft or less. As the weight at the end of an interval depends on the rate of climb (which is not constant) and this in turn depends on the aircraft’s weight, an iterative solution is required for each step of the climb.18 Following the climb calculation, the conditions at the top of climb (TOC) are established.

The cruise fuel and cruise time are based on a numerical integration of the range equation,19 i.e. the solution is not based on an idealised, closed-form equation, such as the Breguet range equation. This was done so that an accurate assessment of drag reduction could be undertaken, without the result being distorted by the assumptions necessary to establish an analytical solution. The integrated range technique19 requires the distance from the TOC to the top of descent (TOD) to be known; however, at the start of the calculation, this is not known due to an uncertainty of the descent distance. A trial value for the cruise distance is thus assumed, which is used to compute a trial value for the cruise fuel (and time). The descent calculation then follows with essentially the same program logic as used in the climb. The final results are compared to the specified mission, and iterations follow until the appropriate TOC to TOD distance has been determined.

In Mode 1, the payload is specified and the range is the unknown parameter. The cruise distance is determined by iteration as described above, where each iteration cycle determines the fuel required for a trial cruise distance. Convergence is attained when the available mission fuel is consumed. In Mode 2 (Figure 2), the range is specified and hence a trial BRW has to be used as the starting point for the calculation. The computation is repeated until convergence of within 0.01% of the aircraft weight is reached. In Mode 3, all three input parameters (i.e. BRW, range and payload) are specified and the mission fuel is calculated. When the aircraft lands at the alternate airport following the defined mission (including the final reserve segment) in the case of Modes 1 or 2, the fuel on board the aircraft would exactly equal the en route contingency fuel. However, this is not that case for Mode 3. The fuel on board at the time of landing at the alternate airport will not, in general, be equal to the contingency fuel. The difference between the on-board fuel and the contingency fuel is the ‘tankered’ fuel (negative quantities indicate that insufficient fuel was uploaded for the mission). Figure 2.
Flowchart of calculations for Mode 2 ‘Range’ (adapted from Young20).
BRW: brake release weight; OEW: operating empty weight; TOC: top of climb; TOD: top of descent; ZFW: zero fuel weight.

sec.title: Aircraft and engine data
sec.p: The original database for this program was for a generic twin-engine jet, in the class of the B757, referred to as the B7G7 by Boeing.30 The database was subsequently adapted and revised by the author to represent different aircraft types (e.g. B757-200 and A330-200).21,31–33 As Model B is in the general class of the A319, data for this aircraft34 was used as a baseline to establish a reference model for this study. The pertinent information that had to be established included: (a) drag polars; (b) climb thrust; (c) corrected fuel flow; (d) minimum idle in-flight thrust and fuel flow; (e) fuel and the time from brake release to 1500 ft; and (f) speed schedules for climb, descent, alternate cruise and final reserve.

No single source of information was available to establish the required database and it was thus necessary to ‘back-engineer’ the data. The most important data for the purpose of calculating the trip fuel is the drag polar and the fuel flow data, and to a lesser extent, the climb thrust data. This was established, in an iterative manner, using scaled generic values as input to the computer program, and by conducting checks of the program outputs against available performance information (e.g. time to climb, long range and maximum range cruise speeds, crew fuel planning tables and payload–range charts). The process is illustrated in Figure 3. Figure 3.
Process adopted for establishing the aircraft databases.

After establishing the basic performance data for the reference aircraft, the data were initially modified to best represent the Model B and Model BER aircraft and then further revised for the Model A and Model AER aircraft.

sec.title: Aerodynamic data
sec.p:
The drag data are contained in a look-up table of CD against CL for Mach numbers from 0.30 to 0.70 in steps of 0.05, and for Mach numbers from 0.72 to 0.84 in steps of 0.1. The drag polars for the Model B and Model A were based on those of a generic aircraft of this class, and modified, in an iterative manner, by introducing scale factors. The resulting drag polars for the Model B aircraft are illustrated in Figure 4 for two selected Mach numbers. The drag polars for Model A are 1.5% lower than that of the Model B aircraft, as it has a shorter fuselage with the same wing. Figure 4.
Estimated low- and high-speed drag polars for Model B.

sec.title: Engine database
sec.p: The adopted approach involved two separate steps: (a) initially, a generic engine database was established for the reference aircraft and (b) the database was then adjusted, in an iterative manner, to best align with available SFC and payload–range information for Model A and Model B, using the trail aerodynamic data.

The rate of climb of an aircraft is dependent on the excess of thrust to drag, for a given weight and speed. Providing that the drag data are approximately correct, calculated time-to-climb values and distance to TOC values (for various weights) provide a mechanism to assess the climb thrust data. The computer program was used to calculate the time-to-climb to initial cruise altitude, the fuel used and the distance covered for a range of BRWs. These results were compared to available data for the reference aircraft, and scaling factors used to adjust the climb thrust data until an acceptable match was achieved.

The engine fuel burn database consists of tables of corrected fuel flow data at selected heights (interpolation is used to establish values at other heights). The SFC is not used implicitly, as the fuel is based on the corrected fuel flow at the required thrust. In the cruise, the thrust is taken as being equal to the drag; however, in the climb, it is established by the time-to-climb and in descent, it is idle.

The cruise sub-routine of the computer model was used with the trial fuel flow database to determine the fuel required for various cruise distances. These results were compared to integrated range data given in the Flight Crew Operating Manual (FCOM) of similar aircraft. Adjustments were made to the fuel flow correction factors, until an acceptable correlation was achieved.

Finally, the resulting database was used to generate SFC data, for comparative purposes – for example, a plot of SFC versus thrust for Mach 0.78 at 35,000 ft is shown in Figure 5. Figure 5.
SFC at 35,000 ft, ISA.
SFC: specific fuel consumption.

sec.title: Operational data and reference speeds
sec.p: The initial climb segment – from takeoff to 1500 ft, with the aircraft accelerating to 250 KCAS (knots calibrated airspeed) – is difficult to analyse numerically. Statistical data are used. The look-up table for the climb data consists of fuel weight, distance and time, from brake-release to 1500 ft, as a function of the BRW. The data for the Model B and Model A aircraft were estimated based on the assumption that the time for the aircraft to accelerate from rest to 1500 ft would not vary significantly within this class of aircraft. The fuel required for this portion of the mission was obtained by scaling available data using maximum takeoff weight (MTOW).

The climb/descent speed schedule was 250/300/M0.78. This implies that the aeroplane climbs at 250 KCAS until flight level (FL) 100 is reached; above this height the speed is held at 300 KCAS until Mach 0.78 is reached, and thereafter a constant Mach number is maintained. The height at which 300 KCAS corresponds to Mach 0.78, i.e. the crossover height,18 is 29,314 ft.

The cruise Mach number was 0.78, and the initial cruise altitude varied between 35,000 and 39,000, depending on the takeoff weight. A 4000 ft step climb (2000 ft in the case of the Model A) was introduced for distances of 2000 nm or greater. The step climb was introduced at the point where the initial cruise weight was reduced by 7.5%.

The alternate leg is typically flown at the aircraft’s maximum range speed (MRS), which is the speed where the specific air range is a maximum. An altitude of 20,000 ft was selected (the alternate distance was 100 nm). The 45 min reserve flight segment is assumed to be at the aircraft s long range cruise (LRC) speed at a height of 39,000 ft. Both speeds were estimated from the established aerodynamic data. This information was also used as a ‘sanity’ check on the aerodynamic data.

sec.title: Model accuracy
sec.p: The purpose of the computer program is to assess comparative changes in fuel usage for a LF aircraft against an equivalent turbulent design. It was thus not necessary that the program be capable of calculating trip fuel to the same accuracy as the software used by an aircraft manufacturer for flight operations, but rather that the predicted trip fuel be close enough so that conclusions drawn from the comparative answers are valid for the class of aircraft studied.

Three critical points on payload–range charts (Figure 6), for each of the four aircraft variants, were selected for this comparison. The range was then determined for the corresponding payload (the mission rules are explained in ‘Trade (sensitivity) studies’). The mean difference between the range values predicted by the computer model and the payload–range data for the twelve cases considered was 1.8%. This was deemed to be well within the requirements for the study. Figure 6.
Critical points on the payload–range chart for the Model BER aircraft.

As several iterative procedures are executed within the computer program (Figure 2), it was necessary to ensure that the output was repeatable. This requirement was demonstrated by running the model 10 times for selected payload–range combinations – negligible deviation in the predicted range values was noted.

sec.title: Correction factors for HLFC and NLF
sec.p: The basic computer program (described in ‘Aircraft data’) was adapted to take into account the potential impact on the trip fuel of HLFC or NLF on the engine nacelles. HLFC represents the more complex case; the changes made to the computer model to assess HLFC were sufficient to study NLF. The program can accommodate changes to the following: (a) the installed weight of the HLFC system; (b) the drag reduction due to the LF; and (c) the SFC change. The program is structured in a way that enabled the drag reduction and SFC penalty to be applied to selected parts of the mission. The mission is divided into discrete elements (e.g. climb, cruise and descent) and these elements are further divided into segments (to facilitate the calculation of the time and the fuel required). The climb and descent are divided into eight segments (nine stations) and the cruise into 20 segments (21 stations). The correction factors can be individually allocated to each station or applied uniformly to all stations. In this way, the impact of LF (or a temporary loss of LF) for a portion of the mission can be assessed.

sec.title: HLFC system weight penalty
sec.p: The installed weight of the HLFC system is added to the basic OEW of the aircraft. If the payload is fixed, this increase will imply a greater takeoff weight, and hence an increased fuel burn throughout the mission. Certain missions, however, are MTOW limited (combinations of payload and range where this is the case can be seen on the upper right-hand boundary of the payload–range diagram). If the payload does not change, the fuel load must be reduced.

sec.title: Drag reduction
sec.p: The drag reduction due to the LF region on the nacelle is treated as a change to the aircraft drag coefficient (ΔCD). In the execution of the program, the total aircraft drag coefficient is determined at each station (based on the calculated lift coefficient) and the drag correction applied. This approach was adopted because the profile drag is reduced by the delay in the laminar-to-turbulent flow transition, but the lift-dependent drag component is essentially unchanged in the presence of the HLFC system.

For reference purposes, the drag change has also been calculated as a percentage of the mean drag of the turbulent baseline aircraft in cruise (determined at the 21 cruise stations) for the particular mission of interest. The drag reduction (ΔCD) is expressed as a fraction of this mean value (Tables 3 and 4). Table 2.

sec.title: Specific fuel consumption
sec.p: The conventional approach for this type of analysis is to establish an ‘exchange rate’ between the power off-take (from the engines) required to drive the HLFC suction pumps and the resulting SFC increase. The computer program, however, does not use SFC to determine the fuel burn. Instead, the fuel flow is directly found at each station from look-up tables of corrected fuel flow for the calculated engine thrust. The HLFC system fuel penalty is incorporated as a percentage increase in the fuel flow. A prior investigation had established that an SFC penalty of 0.09% was required to generate the necessary HLFC suction for the extended LF runs that resulted in the forecast drag reduction.

It should be noted, however, that the use of a single average SFC penalty is adequate for the cruise, but it introduces a minor inaccuracy for the upper part of the climb. The pump power required to produce the required suction (to maintain the LF) reduces with increasing height.36 The height that the HLFC becomes operational is thus an important consideration in determining the overall fuel savings. In this study, it has been assumed that the system is operational above 29,000 ft, based on work conducted in the HYLDA and ALTTA projects.13,14,36 The increased suction power required for the climb segment has been ignored (i.e. the same SFC penalty as used in the cruise was applied to the upper part of the climb).

sec.title: Methodology
sec.p: The development of an optimum HLFC design for an aircraft is non-trivial due to the high degree of inter-dependence that exists between the structural, aerodynamic and systems design parameters. As an input to this optimisation, trade (sensitivity) studies that evaluate the impact on the trip fuel, due to changes to the OEW, SFC and CD, are required. In the case of a NLF design, the situation is simpler as there is no SFC change.

Three sets of calculations to determine the trip fuel were performed for selected combinations of payload and range.
The OEW was increased in small steps, corresponding to an increase of 100, 200 and 300 lb, whilst the SFC and CD were unchanged.
The SFC was incrementally increased, corresponding to an increase of 0.06%, 0.09% and 0.12%, whilst the OEW and CD were unchanged.
The CD was reduced (by 0.000066, 0.000281 and 0.000597), whilst the SFC and OEW were unchanged. This corresponded to LF on the nacelle of 5%, 20% and 40%, respectively.
The resulting change in trip fuel for the aircraft can be obtained by superimposing the results for the three parameters, which were evaluated separately.

The SFC and drag changes were implemented above 29,000 ft for the main mission (not the alternate leg), but the mass change affected the OEW of the aircraft. For each ‘flight’, the lowest BRW was determined for the specified range (using program Mode 2), which ensured that the smallest fuel quantity was calculated each time. The resulting change in trip fuel was determined as a percentage of the fuel required for the baseline turbulent model and plotted against the variable parameter.

Two points on the payload–range graph were selected for analysis. The first corresponded to the maximum structural payload (point A) and the second to the design payload (point B), as shown in Figure 7. Both points were taken close to the maximum range, at approximately 93% of the permissible range at that payload. The points were not selected on the boundaries of the payload–range graph to avoid encountering a MTOW limitation when considering either increased SFC or increased OEW. This combination of variables meant that 24 studies were undertaken (Table 2). Figure 7.
Payload–range graph for Model B and Model BER aircraft, indicating points of interest.

sec.title: Rationale
sec.p: HLFC is essentially a technology that will save fuel during the cruise – this will obviously favour long-range missions over short-range operations. The impact of range on the fuel-saving potential of HLFC may be assessed by considering the ratio of cruise fuel to block fuel. For a trip distance of 500 nm, the fuel consumed in cruise represents about 36–40% of the total fuel burn (based on the assumptions made regarding the mission profile and fuel allowances). At the shorter distances, the taxi, climb and descent fuel elements constitute a significant portion of the block fuel. As the range increases, the cruise-fuel to block-fuel ratio increases and for a trip distance of 3000 nm, the ratio is about 85%. It is interesting to note that this ratio of cruise-fuel to block-fuel is essentially independent of aircraft type. Robert37 of Airbus, for example, showed that for the A340 the ratio is also about 85% for this distance.

sec.title: HLFC study
sec.p:
The method that was adopted for this study is as follows.
The selected trip distances are at or near the limits of the payload–range chart. On the right hand boundary, the selected points are approximately 93% of the maximum allowable range at that payload (see Figure 16 as an example).
The BRW and trip fuel are calculated according to the mission rules (section ‘Fuel planning requirements (mission rules)’), flight profile (Figure 1) and speed/height schedule (section ‘Operational data and reference speeds’).
The HLFC system was then ‘installed’ with the following correction factors: (a) HLFC drag reduction of 0.000597; (b) weight increase of 200 lb (i.e. 100 lb per nacelle); and (c) SFC increase of 0.09%.
The fuel was recalculated assuming optimised fuel planning (i.e. with Mode 2, which allows the BRW to reduce), and the difference in trip fuel between the turbulent baseline aircraft and the HLFC aircraft determined.

sec.title: Potential fuel savings for the fleet
Fleet utilisation model
sec.p:
In this section, the potential fuel savings for the entire aircraft fleet (with the incorporation of HLFC or NLF) has been estimated using an aircraft utilisation model (Figure 21), which represents the probability of the aircraft flying a given stage length. For the purposes of this study, the fleet utilisation data were divided into the following stage length bands: (a) 150–500 nm; (b) 500–1000 nm; (c) 1000–1500 nm; (d) 1500–2000 nm; and (e) 2000–2500 nm. The number of flights that fell within each band was determined. It was then assumed that each band could be represented by a single stage length, mid-way through the band. The number of flights within each band, for every 100 flights, is given in Table 7. Figure 21.

sec.title: Loss of LF
sec.p: It is well-established that flight through cirrus or haze temporarily disrupts LF. This occurrence was widely reported following the X-21A38 and the Jetstar flight tests.39–41 In later LF flight tests, however, most flights were specifically conducted away from clouds because of the instrumentation used to detect the LF, and little or no substantive data on this effect were obtained. There are two aspects to consider in this study. The first issue concerns the cloud climatology on typical airline routes and the second issue concerns the impact on the potential fuel savings (determined in sections ‘Influence of trip distance’ and ‘Potential fuel savings for the fleet’) due to a premature transition of the boundary layer.

Most researchers (e.g. during the analysis of the Global Atmospheric Sampling Program (GASP) data – see section ‘Cloud climatology’) have assumed that no LF is lost in clear air and that 100% loss occurs when the aircraft flies through visible cloud. This is, however, a simplification of the actual situation as the ice particle sizes and concentrations influence the extent of the loss of LF. This was first investigated by Hall;42 subsequent investigations into this phenomenon are reported by Schmidt and Young43 and Schmidt et al.44

sec.title: Cloud climatology
sec.p: A vast quantity of measured data on cloud encounter and particle concentrations on airline routes was obtained during NASA’s GASP from 1975 to 1979.45,46 A statistical analysis to predict the probability of cloud encounter on these airline routes was subsequently undertaken to assess the feasibility of employing LF control (LFC) on long-range aircraft.47–50 It should be noted, however, that the data represents atmospheric conditions in the late 1970s, and there is evidence that the global cloud amount, and in particular cirrus, is increasing.51–53 To forecast a change in global cirrus, so as to assess its impact on future LF aircraft operations, is highly speculative. A rough estimate, based on the results of Parungo,54 suggest a rate of increase of cirrus for the globe of approximately 1% per decade.

sec.title: Net fuel savings using a ‘knock-down’ factor
sec.p: The route average time-in-cloud (TIC) during cruise, as reported by Jasperson et al.,48 varied from a low of 2.2% to a high of 9.9% based on the GASP data. These route average TIC values and the widely-quoted estimate of 7% TIC of Davis et al.40 have previously been used in support of the economic viability of NLF or HLFC, by assuming that LF will, on average, occur during most of the flight.

This approach leads to a simple ‘knock-down’ factor being applied to calculated fuel savings. This is best applied to an average or fleet study, rather than to an individual flight. The net fuel savings for this study, based on the calculated (gross) fleet fuel savings (determined in section ‘Potential fuel savings for the fleet’) and a 7% ‘knock-down’ factor, are recorded in Table 12. sec.title: Taking credit for LF drag reduction for fuel planning
sec.p: Routine fuel planning requirements (section ‘Fuel planning requirements (mission rules)’) for airline operations must take into account expected meteorological conditions and, furthermore, the contingency fuel must be sufficient for deviations from the forecast conditions. It has previously been argued by Young and Fielding21 and Young et al.55 that the calculation of the required trip fuel for LF aircraft should be based on the probable loss of LF during the flight and not on the requirement that the aircraft be capable of completing the mission in the ‘turbulent mode’. When HLFC or NLF is applied to only the engine nacelles, the fuel saving is less than the contingency fuel (this would not be the case for HLFC applied to the wings and empennage).

The final part of this study explored the use of a baseline TIC value, selected as 7% TIC, for the fuel planning (i.e. credit was taken for the drag reduction, but with the proviso that it would be inoperative for 7% of the time). The standard contingency fuel (5%) was compared to the fuel that would be required to complete the mission when greater amounts of cloud (than that assumed for the fuel planning) were encountered. The computer program was run several times (in Mode 3) with a fixed BRW and trip distance (corresponding to the payload–range cases defined in Table 2), but each time the program was set so that the model would encounter increasing ‘actual’ TIC. As expected, the ‘actual’ fuel trip fuel did not exactly match the planned fuel. When the ‘actual’ TIC was greater than 7%, some of the contingency fuel was required to complete the mission. The main conclusion was that the amount of fuel needed in these situations does not exceed 14% of the available contingency, even when considering the occurrence of 50% TIC, which is regarded as an extremely unlikely occurrence.49,50

list-item.p: For small changes to the input parameters (i.e. OEW, SFC and drag), it has been shown (section ‘Trade (sensitivity) studies’) that it is acceptable to consider the effect on the objective function (i.e. trip fuel) of each parameter individually; trip fuel changes due to the combined effect of these parameters can thus be obtained by superposition. This conclusion, coupled with the results of the trade studies (Figures 8 to 16) provide a rapid means to determine the fuel-saving potential of NLF or HLFC engine nacelle concepts for realistic combinations of OEW, SFC and drag changes. The results can be used as input for design optimisation studies of LF nacelles.

Trip distance has a significant influence on the fuel-saving potential of HLFC or NLF aircraft (section ‘Influence of trip distance’). The results for the four aircraft variants are very similar – indicating that the influence of aircraft weight, payload and mission profile (e.g. cruise altitude) is secondary to the influence of range. Relatively, small fuel savings are possible for trip distances of less than 500 nm; this improves rapidly with increasing distance until about 2000 nm is reached, at which point the percentage reduction in fuel saving starts to level out (Figures 17 to 20). For the HLFC case considered, the potential fuel saving for this distance is about 1.5%, and for the NLF case (with 40% chord LF), it is about 1.7%.

An assessment of the potential fuel savings for the aircraft fleet was conducted using a representative aircraft utilisation model (section ‘Potential fuel savings for the fleet’). For the HLFC study, the baseline data (i.e. drag reduction of 0.000597, weight increase of 200 lb and SFC increase of 0.09%) were assumed. Gross fleet fuel savings of between 0.94% and 1.3% are predicted. For the NLF study, gross fleet fuel savings were calculated for three design conditions: transition at 5%, 20% and 40% of the nacelle chord. The results (Table 11) indicate a range of fuel savings from a low of 0.15% (NLF to 5% chord) to a high of 1.55% (NLF to 40% chord for Model AER).

To obtain an accurate prediction of the fuel saving that is possible for an entire fleet under operational conditions, it is necessary to take into account the probable loss of LF due to flight through cirrus (section ‘Cirrus and loss of LF’). A simple ‘knock-down’ factor of 7% on the calculated gross fuel saving has been suggested to predict the net fuel saving for the fleet.

It is suggested that the calculation of the required trip fuel (e.g. for flight operations) for a LF aircraft be based on the probable loss of LF during the flight (e.g. flight in cirrus) and not on the requirement that the aircraft be capable of completing the whole mission in the ‘turbulent mode’. This approach reduces the takeoff fuel load and, consequently, the actual trip fuel. When LF technologies are applied to engine nacelles (as in this study) less than 14% of the contingency fuel was required to accommodate a flight when LF was ‘lost’ for 50% of the time (an occurrence which is regarded as extremely unlikely).
